title: LabWebsite
text: We are a group of spatial ecologists interested in how heterogeneity in space and time affects ecological and evolutionary processes. Our research focuses on forests from the scale of genes to ecosystems, with particular emphasis on forest disturbances such as wildfires and insect outbreaks. Using empirical, simulation, and statistical modelling approaches, we seek to improve our understanding of the links between forest patterns and processes to better forecast the consequences of land-use and climate change on forest health and to inform forest policy.

title: Léo Jourdan
text:
Léo is in his fourth year of undergraduate studies in Computer Science and Mathematics at the University of Toronto. In the James Lab, he is currently helping to devise a method for analyzing point clouds collected from forests using a Terrestrial LiDAR Scanner. This work brings a new element to Léo’s studies, as he is changing paths to focus on the environment. When not busy changing paths, he is either cooking or thinking about the next thing he is going to cook.




University of Toronto Undergrad: Computer Science and Mathematics




Doing an MScF to compare stands of trees affected by JPBW…
